159093689.review:
it is with a heavy heart that I must address the pervasive issue of hacking and cheating that plagues Deadside, tarnishing what could otherwise be a promising and immersive gaming experience. Deadside initially captured the attention of players with its expansive open-world environment and intense survival mechanics. However, the game's potential is overshadowed by the rampant spread of hacking and cheating, which has transformed what should be a thrilling struggle for survival into a frustrating and unfair ordeal.

One of the most glaring manifestations of hacking and cheating in Deadside is the prevalence of aimbots and wallhacks in player-versus-player (PvP) encounters. It is disheartening to witness skilled players being overshadowed by individuals who rely on automated aim assistance to gain an unfair advantage. The result is an unbalanced and demoralizing gameplay experience, where victory is not determined by skill or strategy, but by the ability to exploit illicit software.

Furthermore, the integrity of Deadside's economy is undermined by players who engage in duping exploits and item manipulation. This not only devalues in-game currency and items but also disrupts the delicate balance of the game's economy, rendering legitimate gameplay progression meaningless. As a result, honest players are left feeling disillusioned and disenfranchised, with their hard-earned efforts overshadowed by the exploits of cheaters.

Despite numerous reports from the community regarding hacking and cheating, the response from the developers has been disappointingly inadequate. While occasional ban waves may temporarily address the symptoms of the problem, the root causes remain largely unaddressed, allowing cheaters to resurface with impunity. This lack of decisive action only serves to embolden cheaters and perpetuate a toxic gaming environment where fair play is a rare commodity.

In conclusion, the pervasive presence of hacking and cheating in Deadside represents a significant blemish on an otherwise promising survival game. Unless urgent measures are taken to address this issue, the game risks losing its player base and tarnishing its reputation irreparably. As a fan of Deadside and the survival genre as a whole, I implore the developers to prioritize the fight against hacking and cheating, lest the integrity of the game continue to decay into oblivion.

161405453.review:
I truly feel this game is a hidden gem. Guns and ammo are common, but you need them to get food and water. You start by taking out scavs with whatever low tier gear you find (almost Immediately) then eventually snowball up to fortresses with soldiers and military grade weapons. AI is challenging but fair. Accuracy and damage is very realistic. Low tier AI will miss you a lot. Soldiers are another story. 3 to 4 hits from a good rifle will kill you even with the best armor. 

What I personally appreciate about Deadside is how quickly you get the things you need to actually ENJOY the game. Need a gun? Look in almost any structure and you'll find one with the required ammo right next to it. Need meds? Rip up the clothes of that guy you just shot in the face and heal without consequence. Need rations? Look around any town. Its that simple, which takes away that frustrating grind that comes along way too often in this genre where you spend almost all of your time farming an absurd amount of components just so you can hopefully craft the things you need to have an enjoyable experience. The survival aspect is pleasantly light and only really comes into play when maintaining, such as weapon upkeep or finding food and water. It makes it to where you play on any server for an hour and still have a lot of fun. If you have time to play longer, there are things to strive for. (better gear, better meds, a respectable ration stash). 

I'm not sure why some people have been so hard on the game in the past. Maybe it had some kinks at first that ruined some people's enthusiasm, but my experience so far has been extremely smooth. You can tell its not finished yet, but everything in game works fine. If you're looking for a well balanced survival/looter shooter where you're ready to party in 10 minutes or less, then look no further. I have no doubt that this game will be a huge success in the near future. Really looking forward to land vehicles.

161299528.review:
Currently, I do not recommend the game. Deadside promises an exhilarating blend of extraction shooter dynamics within a persistent open world that mixes PVP, PVE, and survival elements. However, while the gunplay stands out, several areas leave room for improvement:

1. Endgame and Incentives: Deadside suffers from a glaring absence of endgame content, which diminishes its replay value. The gameplay loop lacks compelling incentives to keep players engaged over the long term, feeling somewhat unrewarding as hours progress.

2. Traversal and AI Challenges: The game's reliance on extensive walking and running exacerbates the tedium, especially given the sparse options for faster travel. Boats sporadically appear but hardly mitigate the extensive downtime between actions. Additionally, the AI behavior doesn’t help, with enemies often acting in a predictable manner and lacking sophistication.

3. Building and Customization: The building mechanics are not only slow and uninteresting but also offer minimal gameplay advantages, reducing motivation to invest time in constructing personalized spaces. This is compounded by a disappointing lack of diversity in weapon skins and gear customization, making it hard to personalize the visual experience.

4. Mission Structure and NPC Diversity: The missions are too widely dispersed, requiring lengthy travel times that disrupt the game's pacing. The lack of diversity among NPCs and the absence of structured quests or objectives further strip away the sense of purpose and progression that could enhance the player's experience.

Conclusion: While Deadside delivers robust gunplay, it ultimately falls short in several key areas. The game needs significant enhancements in content variety, AI sophistication, and overall incentives to evolve beyond its current limitations and fully realize its ambitious survival shooter concept. For now, it remains a mixed bag—appealing perhaps for short bursts but lacking enough depth for sustained play.

159945734.review:
I wanted a DayZ clone that respected my time, and that was more grounded. No zombies, just PvPvE survival and looting. Deadside on the surface appears to be that and I'll probably keep playing it. So this isn't a "this sucks" Not Recommended, simply a "probably not yet if ever" one. 

Combat is barebones and doesn't feel particularly good. AI is braindead and has no voice acting, so they are audibly indistinguishable from players through walls. you'll pretty rapidly run out of fun, early game things to do that feel like progression-- at which point you'll probably wanna go tackle a mission. But early game ammo is a bit too scarce for the number of AI the game's missions throw at you, and healing items are not very effective. Trader payouts are miniscule and the traders don't buy resources, so you can't farm trees or the like to help fund gear early on-- meaning that death means you're back to running around looking in empty houses for poor quality pistols and the like; Your gear despawns in just a couple minutes. 

To that point, I think the game is trying a bit *too* hard to copy DayZ's systems and the devs would do well to overhaul much of their plundered game design. Compared to DayZ, Deadside is a much faster paced game with more frequent combat, quicker acquisition of playermade spawnpoints (4 or 5 articles of clothing = a sleeping bag) and far more server-generated mission events: it doesn't make sense that the game still insists on the arduous and clunky parts of DayZ. 

Like I said, I plan to watch this game and hope it can become the more relaxed survival experience for when I don't feel like the effort and emotional investment Tarkov demands. So maybe I'll update this review down the line. But for now, I'd look elsewhere for your fix.

The people who run the servers in this game. There are no official servers (yet) and the ones that do say "official" have admins playing on it. The admins have the power to spawn anything they want, teleport anywhere they want, and kick/ban whoever they want. My time in this game has been brought to a discouraging and heartbreaking end because I was recently banned in a server I was doing really well in. I was walking out a building and all of the sudden "This account has been banned." I messaged their discord and I was banned in that too. I simply wanted a reason as to why I was banned and to this day I still do not know why.

Let me first say that there are official servers in this game. However most official servers the ping is way too high for me to play or the servers are pretty dead due to the ping. That’s okay because I get the game is alpha and they don’t have the budget to hold 60 different servers but the official servers are very limited. 67614540.review:
World: The world is a great medium well balance world with small towns and some good POI’s with different tiers of loot. Some trees on the map still float about 1m above the ground, but I found only a few in the world (most on slope areas). About animals *see Survival Elements below.

Weather: I think a weather system would have worked great, it will add to the atmosphere, at the moment it is always clear skies. The day/night cycle works well.

In game Map: The in game map is great, the function of adding multiple marker points on the map to track your user waypoinst/POI's are great, wish every game had it. 

The character: The character looks great, the clothes are nice at the moment, when climbing over objects the character seems to stay on top of the object until you move forward and not just leaping over. You can climb through windows that are very nice for different room access if someone is already in a house building etc. You can set the FOV so that makes the First Person view easier to manage and with a free look button to view realistic angles by moving your neck. Biggest thing I miss in this game regarding the character is to prone (There is no prone), making stealth approaches very difficult. Jumping while running seems like you can’t jump far while running.

Sound: The world sound is nice, for example you can hear the humming noise of a Transmission Tower (Electricity Pylon). But there is an ambient noise that sounds like footsteps, and then you look around and see nothing, you can hear squirrels or small animals in the vegetation which seems realistic. The normal walking in game seems a little bit loud to sneak onto someone. Also making stealth approaches difficult.

Base Building: The base building is still basic but I like it, I think in future updates the base building will be great. You need an axe, saw and hammer to start your build, I think that makes it a bit more realistic and with a team effort you will have a base in no time. (Make sure someone is on guard while you build).Biggest thing that needs to be done on the base building side is for the clan/squad to access the base while the clan/squad leader is offline. 

Survival Elements: You can drink sodas and eat canned foods; I would like to see animals in the world. Maybe to hunt them, or have some fruit trees around to harvest from, it will make the survival aspect easier to manage than to go to the trader and keep on buying food and sodas, and here and there you can find soda and food in houses etc. The dam should be accessible for drinking, maybe have a water container to retrieve the water. (Well this is just a suggestion).

The NPC’s: They come in variety and some are more difficult than others, but I must say they are just perfect.

The Weapons: From Pistols, shotguns, sub machine guns, assault rifles to sniper rifles. A good variety with mod options, on the mod side I would like to see a hunting scope for some of the rifles, and some other new attachments. But we need to wait and see.

The missions: The missions are fun, they also come in different difficulty so that gives you a choice to approach it or not. I would like to see different scenarios of missions; maybe in the future they will add it.

Safe Zone and Traders: There are two safe zones, each with two traders. One where you can buy weapons and gear and other one where you can buy food/soda, tools etc. You can sell looted items to buy new gear etc. There you can also talk to your enemies or friends about what happened in the field.

The Servers: I Personally think the players need access to the server files to host their own servers in the country they reside, playing on a ping of +-200ms with or against players with a ping of 10ms is just unfair but debateable. Not all countries have an Official Server, so consider before you buy, just in case it might be unplayable with excessive high ping. At the moment you need to rent a server but the server will still be hosted elsewhere. A lot of server lags at the moment but I saw the Developers are working on it. 

Buy it/don’t buy it: The game is still early access and has only been released on the 14th Arpil 2020, it is still very new. It is affordable and it comes with a support pack for information on the store page https://store.steampowered.com/app/895400/Deadside/
I will say it is a must buy, the developers are working around the clock to fix the small bugs, they are very interactive with the players and they keep them up to date with what is happening. For a small developer group they have done very well and I think the launch was overwhelming and unsuspected. I see great things for this game. Edit: I am editing this part, on the release I felt that the developers are doing a good job, at the moment they are doing a good job by keeping a selective player base happy and content, on the other hand if you not close to a server you will experience a high ping and will battle to play due to rubberbanding.

Edit: "on the other hand if you not close to a server you will experience a high ping and will battle to play due to rubberbanding." I will have to say, I reinstalled this game after a couple of updates to see if the server issues are resolved, due to no local servers playing it makes it almost impossible. There is no change in ping which is understandable due to server location, but the rubberbanding is non existent, I do believe that when Tinybuild bought into Bad PIxel that they saw a lot of small things that can change, especially on the Server side of things. I am still hopeful for a local server but it is at least playable and the game that I was looking for.


Closing Comment: I will update this review as we go along.

PS. If I encounter and kill you, please forgive me as it is called Deadside for a reason.

Keep safe and enjoy.

130645064.review: A once promising and flourishing game, it has unfortunately taken a turn for the worst since it has been taken over by Tiny Build. The previous team, Bad Pixel, developed a visually immaculate third/1st person option shooter survival set in modern post apocalyptic world with real world weaponry and gear. Unfortunately the small dev team (Bad Pixel) couldn't bring their full game to fruition on their own and signed the game over to Tiny Build who promised they shared the common vision and goals as the originators. Since the take over we've seen unpolished mechanics and game play make it's way into game play. For example, an update removed the option to purchase food in the safe zone in lieu of a canteen to assist with hydration, a key feature in survival games. The canteen is a single use item that cannot be filled in any of the bodies of water located on the map. A recoil pattern spray update was also implemented. Has anyone ever heard of a third person shooter with recoil pattern? How would/could this work? While there are many other issues regarding implementations, other pressing issues to discuss exist such as glitches. One of which is a crouch glitch where you crouch and wedge yourself under a overhanging rock or tree branch, log out, log in, and viola, you're now in another part of the map. Another such glitch is when you die from falling, being killed in air, or your body rolls down hill. When this occurs, you cannot loot your body and all those hours of looting are wasted. The last issue at hand is the lack of vehicles. This game is a running simulator so get ready to build up your finger dexterity! The dev team continues to promise the release of vehicles while missing road map release dates time after time with the promise that they're still working on it. Vehicles have actually been down graded to open platform boats and this is somehow supposed to be appeasing. I'm not saying this game is a complete loss but at this rate and with the lack of meaningful updates, it's looking that way. At the end of the day you can always try it out and get a refund. Good luck out there and have fun.

Bought this game on a whim and couldn't be happier. Don't let the steam charts player count scare you away from this game. There are dedicated servers in this game that always have players in it.

Unlike DayZ and Rust, you can find guns almost immediately when spawning in, in houses and shelters. So you aren't spending hours looking for a firearm, magazines, and ammo. Guns in this game spawn with ammo.

The game currently has two safe zones that you are able to enter and store some of your loot or even sell it to one of the two vendors. One vendor sells ammo, guns, and armor/clothing. The other vendor sells building/crafting supplies and food/meds.

My favorite thing about this game is that there are no OFFLINE RAIDS so you aren't glued to the game like Rust. Depending on the server, when you die you have a chance to drop a raid token and if someone pops the raid token within 5 mins of your death, it triggers your base to be open to be attacked and large general proximity of your base is shown on the map any everyone has ~60 mins to attack. Once the timer is up, you can no longer be raided unless you die and drop another raid token and someone pops it.

Sadly, my thoughts remain the same: This game has potential, quite some, in my opinion, and does some things VERY well. 
BUT. All the good things are overshadowed by a single thing, that has ruined multiple times the experience for me and my friends. 
It's not the animations, it's not the mouse weird acceleration thing going on that makes your aim go funky, it's not the graphics, it's not the boredom after just a few days and the repetitiveness of the gameplay... it's the AI. 
THE. F*****G, AI. 
Let me explain: I stopped playing because we would get headshotted by a single enemy controller by the AI running in a field with an SMG and insta-killed. From 200+ meters. With TOP ARMOR. Multiple times.  So you have to respawn in the closest city, run back to your body to get your things back, only to find the bots evaporate you again, and again, and again. And each time you have to spawn further away, because spawns have a cooldown time. Fun, eh?
So we stopped playing out of frustration. 
Then we came back last week because they had "Rebalanced the AI", only to find they kinda did... but there's still a huge underlying issue with the way the devs program difficulty for the harder missions.

Their words:" [i]Getting an instant 180 headshot by an AI using a Mosin is not the experience we are aiming to deliver, and we hope these changes will eliminate that problem"[/i]
I mean, yeah i have multiple videos of me getting evaporated by AIs doing a 180 turn and shooting me with spiderman's reaction time which was kinda bullcrap.
Now? Well, now if you dare to pop your head out of cover you get shot and killed... in 2 shots. I mean, i agree the AI actually turns slower and reacts slower, but we're talking American Sniper's level of accuracy no matter the weapon they use and how far you are. I have videos of AI following me repositioning myself while running hidden from them: use 3rd person, run along a hill, a crest or a shore hidden from view and see how the AI's powerful x-ray eyes follow you wherever you go. 
Oh, and if you dress yourself with a ghillie, set up a .cal50 on a hill and shoot enemies from 500m+, don't expect to live for more than a few seconds. They will kill you with their shoelaces.

This is not "The Dark Souls of Survival FPSs", this is lazy coding.

I do not recommend this game, not until they change the way bots behave.

99860905.review:
Deadside is a pretty controversial game in which people often overlook because of the game style and its similarity to other games. Currently I have 33 hours on the game, and below are some of the things I've experienced and learned in my time, granted not a lot of time but I'll try to explain and make it as clear as possible.
- - - 
Deadside is a medium-fast paced survival game, where you spawn in as a character with little to no supplies, and your goal is to simply live for as long as possible. Sounds simple, right? Well, Deadside is fully open world with an already pretty large map, and has areas around the map that have Scav patrols or even Scav outposts, more commonly however are Scav missions, which all give you varying loot depending on their difficulty. Not only this but there is series of random events that are triggered for players to do, high risk high reward missions. However... there are some catches.
------------
THE PROS: 
1. Surviving isn't impossible but is easily present.
2. Weapons feel like weapons, not like toys.
3. People can focus more on PvE then PvP and still get to use their firearms effectively, appealing to more then one audience.
4. The community is fairly friendly, they're not perfect but from my interactions it's been fine.
5. The game supports traders and limited "vault" storage at these traders, along with a money system for buying and selling items.
6. Additionally with 5, the game supports the ability to trade items with other players, opening line to new possibilities for people who are not PvP gods.
7. The game has a good focus between realism and arcade, running definitely is no stranger in this game; nor is it in any game that's open world survival. However, if you know where to go and stay in the same areas to sort of "farm" loot, you can minimize the running.
8. Deadside supports base building as well, along with a teaming system too.
9. Attachments for weapons are simple to understand and easy to use.
10. In continuation of 9, the entire game is quite self-explanatory give you know basic survival games. The HUD is easy to understand and is straight forward, same with the inventory; managing to be even more simple.
11. They even included skins in the game where if you looted a variant of a gun or vest, it could have a skin applied to it, increasing it's value as a "collectible" so to speak.
12. For the most part I haven't seen any exploiters since I started playing either.
13. Combat is actually fun to play through, and it feels rewarding to truly win a fight.
14. There are plenty of community servers you can choose from to find out which one fits your playstyle best. (I played on Loaf's server in my 33 hours)
-------------
THE CONS:
1. The AI's aiming can be a bit of a hassle sometimes, and it can get annoying when fighting up to 15 scavs in a mission as a solo player, but the load is easier to bare with a team.
2. Some buildings are not fully inside detailed nor are other buildings able to even entered, making it sometimes upsetting to die all because you couldn't open a door.
3. Some settings are lacking in their ability, but others are fully changeable. There is leaning in the game, however it's a hold; not a toggle - and you can't change this setting.
4. Respawning can be the most annoying part as it's hard to get back into an area you want to be in, the same goes with respawning right beside a patrol - which only happens every now and then.
5. Parts of the map lack proper cover, making you easy targets to players and AI alike.
6. There are guns in which are considerably more powerful, that being M99 and VSD (.50 cal and 7.62x54mmR snipers) which can one or two shot most players even with vests; which is controversial as they do seem balanced.
7. There are no vehicles in the game, which can make running even more of a hassle if you spawned 3km away from your body, BUT there is an option to choose your spawn point if you have enough "Rep" points.
- - - -
There are some honorable mentions that this game is not fully completed, it was also recently purchased to help increase the production of the game. It also (as of currently) has more overall upvotes then a game like DayZ does, although it has a fraction of the playerbase.
In the end Deadside is truly a good game, do I expect you to play it everyday? No, not even I do - but it is a good game to come back to and appreciate for it's potential in it's early phases.

67343178.review:
My honest to god review of Deadside (Extremely critical)

First and foremost I have to say, it's a lot of fun... But it does have it's downside, this reviews gonna be mostly positive and I want to help anyone here thinking of making the purchase decide whether it's right for them.

- The first thing I LOVE is the Npc's in the game! Other games like SCUM are rather boring if the player base is low, NPC's give us a chance to get loot, items & weapons... Whilst giving us something to do when no players can be found (they could be offline, base building or just simply camping)
**The npc's are rather terrible right now, with aimbot like aim (i haven't been killed by many but sometimes they do one tap from no where) Their movement is super average too and their "intellegence" isn't very intellegent.

- MISSIONS: this is an absolute god send! So much fun to do, and the fact there is in-game events like Helicopter crashes & loot crates makes it so dynamic and a ton of fun to get around (the heli's and loot crates arent in game yet i dont think)
Missions are what we've been looking for!!

- The vendors makes an in-game currency so the grind now has a "point" - Rather than useless gear stashing, we now can get gear, loot players & take risks because the pay off could be BIG.
Then the ability to buy other weapons is amazing.

Now for the BAD. (My comments are taking in account for the fact it's EARLY game, my BIGGEST worry is these issues won't ever be fixed or be a priority because they have "other focuses")

- AIMING is fucking horrible, clunky & really feels like im playing a playstation 2 game, it's 2020, the animations are poor. It's really bad and I REALLY hope they improve this.

- Textures, no matter which way you swing it, the textures and graphics are very poor, SCUM is a competitor who TAKES THE CAKE. Creating stunning worlds, amazing textures & immersive graphics, this to me is VERY similar to DayZ which is OLD AF.

- MOVEMENT: This is absolutely horrible, glitching everywhere on the screen, hitting random hit boxes through doorways, bouncing around houses & climbing stuff? Forget it. 

- EMPTY world: The locations are basically CABINS. Not any cities and when there is it's almost completely unaccessible, not being able to enter 90% of the buildings. And when there is a "city" it's absolutely poor designed, terrible layout & overall shite.

- Running is too fast or something, players can sprint 100% sprint up a 90% incline hill and it's just a weird feeling.

- AUDIO: As DrDisrespect would say "WHERE IS THE AUDIO!?!?!?!?" The amount of times ALREADY I've had some dude sprint behind me and shoot me and I heard NOTHING and if I heard something It did not sound like it was behind me.

- The world: Again, it feels empty and very small amounts of "towns", you can run through open forests for a long ass time without seeing anything.

- **Important** LOOT: Any PvP survival is RUINED in my opinion by lack of decent guns in the game, finding scopes/red dots etc, should be FAR easier to find as buying them from a VENDOR is a ridiculous price.

OVERALL:
This game reminds me of a 2020 version of Arma 3 Exile or Wasteland... I've been enjoying it and I have HIGH hopes but they are silenced by the rememberence of most other games that promised big things and NEVER delivered, I'm afraid it'll be one of those games that just paints a pretty picture, delivers an early game & then just never does anything with it.

For the price $20 USD $28 AUD is NOTHING for a game & it's really worth giving it a go & finding out if you like it as honestly I've had a ton of fun on this already, lots of PvP and the missions add such a great element to it.

I have high hopes and this game has buckets of potential, if you're willing to take a risk, jump right in, if not, sit it out & wait it out :)

TheWizard, if you see me in game, say hi :)

67308153.review:
About 5 hours in as I write this review. All the negative comments/reviews seem to be due to people not reading before they buy the game. The description clearly states what is currently available in the game and that it's a BASE GAME at the moment. It's between pre-alpha & alpha stages. There's a reason it's listed as Early Access.

With that being said, because I read what I was buying before clicking the buy button, I'm loving it so far. The graphics are smooth as butter on my PC, no lag spikes or horrible stuttering .. and for a game in the $30 range if you get the Supporter Pack, I'm definitely happy with the purchase.

It gives you the survival aspect of needing to approach areas slowly and cautiously, otherwise you make too much noise and alert any players/NPC's in the area and give them plenty of time to spot you and blow your head off. Looting at the moment does feel a bit clunky, but I can see this ironing out over time as they continue working on it.

I'm excited to see what the game is going to have in store over the next 12-18 months that the devs estimate will be the ETA for the full release. If things continue to go the way I hope they do, it has the potential to hit the survival genre in a unique way!


Things I'd love to see added in future updates:

- Animals: The ability to hunt/fish, open areas are vast in this game and I would love to see wildlife roaming around to make it feel alive.

- Secluded cabins/campsites/POI's: Being able to explore the wilderness and happen upon an abandoned hunting camp or a  cabin out in a wooded area would be a lot of fun and give players a reason to go out and explore every inch of the map.

- More loot locations: I noticed that loot seems to be pretty static in it's spawning locations. I enter a building and know exactly where to look. Giving the loot spawning a more random spawning pattern would be ideal.

- The ability to adjust brightness/gamma/contrast: I feel like the game looked a bit washed out at times (depending on the time of day as well). I love bright and vibrant worlds and would love to adjust that in-game.

- Improved audio: When approaching a new town/building I always approach slowly and listen for the sounds of footsteps or branches rustling in the distance to help me just who/how many enemies are close by.

I'll likely update this review as I put more hours in, but I can see incredible potential with this game and hope that updates are pushed through on a fairly quick and regular schedule.

68594581.review:
[h1] A Great Start For An Alpha [/h1]

Let me be clear, this game is in alpha at the time I am writing this and I'm positive that the developers will fix many of the bugs stated as well as add many quality of life features.

[u] My Personal Thoughts [/u]

Something that I immediately noticed when I first hopped into a server was how reminiscent this game is to Escape From Tarkov, another Russian-based game held in a fictional location and time period in which civilization has somewhat or totally collapsed. Many items from the backpack to the armor, the military barracks, many aspects have that Tarkov vibe. This makes sense since both games are being inspired or based off Russia. Another thing I noted was the Day Z vibe. The long stretches of nature with small, distantly-placed towns all create that atmosphere. Needless to say, the state of Day Z in its early access pales in comparison to this game--more on that later. The alpha state of the game shows great promise and developers who seem passionate about their work. Let's begin with some positives!

[u] The Positives [/u]

Let's begin with map design. Having an expansive map to explore can provide many players tons of enjoyment in their conquest for territory and/or their wayward spirits. However, a large map can begin to bring ailments to the game as well. Let us not forget the countless 30-seconds-to-explore caves Skyrim has through its massive world. The saying "As big as an ocean but as deep as a puddle" holds a lot of weight in open-world games. This game doesn't suffer from this greatly since it has many activities to do. My worry is that once they expand the map's boundaries, the game will succumb to this illness and be a walking simulator. Vehicles are hinted at since spark plugs can be found in game which means cars will most likely need it in order to run. This would help with the fear of a walking simulator but would not remedy it completely. As it stands right now, there is fairly enough content within the map to keep players motivated to keep conquering land and exploring while fending off the AI bandits and other players, for now.

I'd like to address the activities the game provides next. With varying difficulties, missions are what drives the players in a server to converge on a place and come out of their hidey-holes and start getting loot. This, in conjunction with the ever-used airdrops and crash sites, offer enough reason for a player, or group, to risk their lives for gear and money. 

A survival game wouldn't be very survivaly without proper weapons to defend yourself, and this game provides a good amount of weapons, for an alpha, to players to tinker around with before finally settling on their preferred weapon. The gun-play seems alright and is nothing special, in my opinion. Bullets don't appear to have ballistics and disappear, [i] a la instance destroy [/i], which makes snipers feel odd but not totally useless. 

Safe Zones, and Traders, and Lockers, oh my! It is nice to have an area to breathe in where you can exchange your hard-earned loot for some cash. While the trader's HUD is simplistic, it isn't needlessly complex with countless sub-menus to confuse players. I also like the idea of reputation being a  separate currency obtained from dog tags (Tarkov, anyone?) which serves as a way to spawn somewhere you choose when you inevitably die.

Animation is pretty good and feels natural. I really do feel like my character is sluggishly thumpping on the ground when I'm wearing 100lbs of armor and weapons, topped with 40 cans of that sweet, sweet tomato soup from Campbe-, well whatever funny name they will come up with.

Onto some negatives

[u] The Negatives [/u]

Audio. My god the audio. If you aren't crapping yourself to the sound of a woodpecker reminding you of Vietnam flashbacks, you are crapping yourself when yourself when a flurry of invisible birds just flap away at a moments notice. Right away, I noticed the lack of bass in the audio. None of the guns have a beefy sound which makes them sound very distant when shot in hand or up close. I've used the VSD a lot and, my gosh, when I fire it, it sounds like someone firing it 100 meters away. Even when someone shoots it 100 meters away, it sounds the exact same except slightly quieter. Not all guns are like this, namely the pistols. All of them sound fair in what caliber they are. But how is a 5.56x45 quieter than a 7.62x54r round? Unless they are subsonic rounds, that shouldn't be. I'm confident in saying that ALL of the pistols sound louder than the VSD. Audio is a heavy aspect that players rely on to pinpoint an enemies position. Without good audio, a player won't get the feeling that the gun they are using, like a sniper, can be heard miles away versus, say, a pistol. I really hope that in future updates that weapons will get two or maybe three kinds of audio: one loud audio when up close or in hands, another when heard from a distance or when coming inside a building, and another echoing throughout a large area when heard from afar.

Another issue I have is the food and soda (there is no water) in game. It isn't really clear which food is better apart from their price as their is no way for the player to know which food replenishes what. Not something game breaking but something that requires some tuning.

Ammo is something else I'd like to discuss. Ammo should have different stacking caps depending on the caliber since all ammo stacks to 100. Carrying 100 rounds of 7.62x54R is a hell of a lot different than carrying 100 rounds of 7.62x25. They weigh different, they take up different amounts of space and should be adjusted to such. It doesn't have to be drastic (like in Unturned, another survival game) where the player is cumbered by rounds for only two mags, but it should be something the player has to decide which weapon is better: the one that does more damage but can only stack 40 rounds, or the gun that does less damage but can have 100 rounds.

Bugs. The plague that every game ever created has endured (I'm looking at you Fallout 76). This game doesn't have a lot of bugs despite being in alpha, there is a commendable amount of polish in this game that [i] some [/i] AAA studios don't do in a full-released game. However, a MAJOR bug does exist. There is some duplication glitch that allows players to duplicate items which ruins the progression system of the game. I've unintentionally duplicated my items when my teammate killed me and I killed him by swinging an axe at him while chopping a tree (don't ask how I did nor ask why I went to the same tree). I'm sure this will be fixed soon since this is a glaring bug which threatens the game's progression system.

Building a base is fun with friends, but it is not fun when only one player in a group can build in their own claimed area and HAS to be on in order for other teammates to open doors and such. A small bug but a big inconvenience. 

There are probably a lot more bugs and issues that I've experienced but hasn't come to mind in the time of writing this.

[u] A Conclusion to a Word Wall [/u]

Overall, I have high hopes for this game due to how fleshed out its early access is. While there are negative aspects that I mentioned above, I wouldn't consider it a deterring factor. Playing with friends is really fun and getting into the heat of combat makes for a thrilling experience. Here is to a promising survival game!

I have taken some proper time to play this game and put some hours in. i have been playing since the day it came out so i feel i can make an honest judgment of the game. With that said here is my review. 

The game itself fundamentally works pretty well. Spawn. Get loot. Grind for higher loot. Sell and repeat. While the game idea works good i think there could be more of an improvement made to the tier tables and how high tier loot is obtained and used. Once you are at the top of the food chain there isnt anything to do but go to the military bases back and forth to make money. The game runs pretty good but can get laggy sometimes with large bases and player counts at their max. The looting system could use some work in optomization and making looting more seamless. Bots seem to be in a good spot where you dont know if it is a player or not and i do like that element .Over all it is a good game for 20$ and i will continue to play it with upcoming updates. 

HOWEVER the developers are only a 3 man team! producing content will be slow and the flow of new things to do will be stagnant for a little bit, but i understand that. The game does have its bugs but they are being worked out with every update. Hiring more staff as the game develops will help with this but for the time being with only 3 developers it is very understandable and with what they have done i am impressed. with that said here are somethings i would like to see going forward.

Things i would like to see going forward are:
means of transportation besides walking
more incentive for high loot players to keep playing
a player to player market
more overlapping content like having to find a card in rust to go to oil things like that
and finally a bigger map. getting bored of doing the same thing over and over.

98527276.review:
Deadside is, in short, a love-child between Rust, Tarkov, and DayZ. What all of those games fail to do, Deadside does it so incredibly right. It is in beta, but even so it is far more polished than most other games at this stage. I wholeheartedly recommend getting this game for cheap before it becomes a big hit and becomes more expensive. 

Imagine Escape From Tarkov, but SCAVs are wandering all over the map. Instead of having to go do fetch quests, you can pick up quests just by entering an area. Once those quests are done, you are instantly rewarded with better loot that you can either equip or sell off. The trading system is there and I don't have many qualms about it. 

If you're struggling to get food or water, unlike DayZ, you CAN go to the safe zone to purchase some of those. Think of the safe zone as your "PMC Hideout"; you can store items permanently there and you can talk with traders to get weapons, ammo, equipment, food, and more. If you want your own true hideout you can always build one. 

If you aren't into PvP, you can go on PvE servers (in my experience, the people on PvE are really bros). PvE provides enough enemies that you can have some fun on your own. As you go into harder areas or into more difficult quests, the enemies can become more and more overwhelming. I don't think that there is a lack of enemies and I don't foresee a lack of engaging gameplay being a problem.

Because the game is in BETA, there are some issues. Enemies will spawn on top of you sometimes if you are in a city or town, and because of how large the map is you will start getting shot at before you even see enemies (granted, their aim is terrible at far range). The AI for bandits needs work; most of them charge out toward you and don't take defensive positions. That being said, there have been times where I have been genuinely impressed with the AI. In my first encounter with bandits, my friend and I both believed we had been attacked by players because of their maneuvering. However, there still needs to be a lot of work done to them given that they are at the core of gameplay. 

I do wish that there was more early weapon variety, but it is there and it does contribute to a sense of progression. I wish that there were better options for wound treatment such as EFT's medkit system. Finding the resources to make bandages can be a bit of a hassle at times, and I wish that you could create/carry a medkit with multiple uses. I think that something like this will be added in the future. Food and drinks are THERE but I think their spawns might need to be bumped up just a little bit.

The graphics for the game are actually very nice given the early state of the game. I would love to see some enhancements to the graphics, especially for visual clarity purposes. Some depth of field and changes to lighting would do a lot of favors. The trees in the game are truthfully awful looking but I never felt as though it detracted significantly from gameplay.

Overall, I am more than excited to see where the developers take the game from here!

156716144.review: I currently have 450 hours in the game, and will continue to play. I have experience in Rust and Dayz and I can say this game has been my favorite out of all. The simplicity makes this game a better pick for anyone who don't have time to play 24/7. You cannot get raided unless you die to another online player, and even then there is a chance you won't drop a raid token. Once your raid token is popped, any other players in server have 1 hour to gather c4 and raid your base. It takes 1 c4 for any type of build to destroy. (Loot boxes are not lootable for others not assigned to base, only when raid is active of course.) There are many missions scattered around the map varying from easy to epic. There are also loot drops and convoys that give high tier military loot (weapons, attachments, and even better armor). There are also different places around the map that contain locked crates which can be opened with red keys found at heli crashes, dead NPC's clothing, or mission crates. Inside these locked crates are various types of guns with many different possible camos that can only be obtained by opening these crates. Loot obtained from missions, drops, etc. can be stored at any of the two safe zones located north and south of the map (Large green circles). Once loot storage is full, you can sell unwanted things to trader, or you can obtain a hammer, axe, nails, and wood and start building your base! Doors can be locked with code locks, and crates can be made to store loot. (8 crates max as of this update) There are many guides on the game as i cannot explain everything. This game has exceeded my expectations leading me to leave this giant review. I highly recommend giving this game a try as it goes on sale often, even though it is already a fantastic price for what the Devs have givin us!

126416026.review:
The only way I can describe this game is to bring up other games. If you've ever played DayZ/SCUM/ArmA Exile/survival base-building game #34678, and cringe at the thought of how crippling emotionally it is when you lose all of your stuff, then this game might be the solution you've been looking for. It definitely was for me.

     Deadside is an open world/basebuilding/survival game that trims all the fat off of the genre and leaves mostly just the fun parts of these games. Most major towns are respawn points, and you can craft and place down respawn beacons(with small limits like no  safezones) for yourself. Weapons are easy to come by. AI is cheesable even solo, and the map is big enough that you aren't getting smoked in the rear constantly by 16 yr old Tanner and his gaggle of fraternity fuckbois. The TTK(time to kill) is very short, almost Tarkov-esque without the non-pen bullet spongyness. A naked freshie with a shotgun can easily solo a 2-man group and even 3-man if they are occupied with mission AI.

     Randomly generated missions keep you on that dopamine drip with "lootboxes" that drop good weapons/meds/food/building supplies. AI is laser accurate when they are military bots, but cover and peeking do a really good job of mitigating this. All in all most missions are soloable if you have experience with jiggle peeking and repositioning.

YOU CAN NOT BE RAIDED WHILE OFFLINE (thank God)

     Gone are the days of logging in to an empty base. When players kill you, there is a 20% chance you will drop a "raid token". This token will expire and can't be hoarded, but once activated will show the "general" location of your base on the map to all players and at that point becomes raidable. The only way to get raided is to die to other players and even then its only a 20% chance each time you die. You can however die, ragequit, and then wake up to an empty base b/c you werent there to defend, when they popped the token. (whoops, happened to me RIP first base)

     Again, this is just DayZ/SCUM, but its actually fun. Downtime spent running and building are greatly minimized to keep you doing the fun stuff. You even get a run speed buff from being above 89 food/water!

     The developers did a really good job of capturing that old ArmA Wasteland feeling, but making it way more accessible to "gamer dads" or people who don't want to stare at grass for 3 hours while running somewhere for a can of peaches.

     This game makes open world survival actually fun, and capitalizes on making the player feel good about each gun they pick up, building piece they put down, and kill they bag. Nothing takes extraneous amounts of time. Death isn't a big deal. Hell, even losing your base isnt a big deal b/c you can solo missions with a shotgun that have the best loot as the reward.

     A fun DayZ/SCUM that trims all the "funk" from the gameplay model, and focuses on getting the player into whats fun and important. Getting loot and killing players or AI.

CONS
-No zombies (a PRO for me honestly)
-Gunplay can be wonky like holding breath after shift-sprinting too fast will cause you to re-enter "walk" 
   mode instead of just ADS'ing like you want it to.
-AI can be bullshit but the harder ones are supposed to be b/c the loot is phenomenal.
-This game is harsh on solos when it comes to PVP, but if you are good at PVP, it can be as much of an 
   adrenaline rush as Tarkov/DayZ fighting and winning against a 2-3 man group.
-I wouldn't say the game "needs more content", b/c im having a blast playing it regardless, but it definitely 
   could use more guns/attachments/loot types/points of interest. The PVP is what I stay to play for, but I 
   would love to see a wider variety of tools to kill people and AI with.
-Supporter pack gives skins which sends the wrong message to people. The game doesn't MTX skins at all. 
   The skins in game you can just paint onto your clothes using a workbench and it costs no materials at all, and there are default in-game camos that make more sense and are more concealing than the supporter pack ones.
- The map doesn't let you zoom in far enough, so examining terrain features and building up close on your map is not even possible. Relying on third-party maps is a must if you want to know where the good loot spawns. This should really be addressed by the devs. I should be able to look at the map closely, see a group of buildings that aren't marked as a "town" or "POI" and realize I've found an unmarked area that might just be ripe for looting. You get robbed of the ability to use these skills by the unzoomable map that lacks alot of terrain detail.


Great game would recommend

7/10, would push Tanner's shit in with my Mosin-Nagant while his homies watch all over again.

67474387.review:
EDIT : UPDATED REVIEW

Game has no anticheat, no base raiding system. The game easily over-rewards those who've grinded the game for either tons of money, a mega base, or very strong gear that doesn't have any durability. Speed hackers galore, private servers are the way to play but at times when admins are offline, esp, aim hack, and speed hackers rule the server. They'll kill you for your hard earned gear or if you manage to kill them, they'll return with a gun an no-recoil you. Game is overall fun but will be easily be overtaken by the shitty cheater community if no counter-measures are put into place. If the devs don't hurry to fix this problem, it is likely that the legit-player playerbase will eventually leave to play some other pvp / survival genre that has an established anti-hack. Please devs, act quickly before it kills your game.


(Following (1st) review based on the first 6 or so hours into the game)

{ E A R L Y - A C C E S S     R E V I E W }

Okay so based off first impression the game is a hybrid game, combining elements of Escape From Tarkov, where you grind for gear and are able to store it along with numerous 'scavs' scattered across the map, and DayZ, where it's survival based, open-world, with a need to eat and drink. Thankfully, the game is more sided toward Escape From Tarkov where as the gameplay is more pvp focused than DayZ. Sure there's a fair share of running around the map, but not equal to the large scale at which DayZ consisted of. For it's price-tag the game is worth, though still lacking some content. Game has a way to go, but if the devs consistently improve the game it'll have a bright future. The map includes two save zones that allow the player to store gear and buy/sell to traders. The game is kept interesting by having consistent spawns of Ai across the map that will try to instantly gun you to the ground. Furthermore there are missions with scaling difficulty that give late-game players a challenge or low-geared freshies a chance to come up on some fat lootables. Overall the movement is a bit clunky at the moment but does include a nifty vault feature which comes into use often. The map's buildings are quite barren and don't really include much furniture. The meta seems to be either hitting military bases and hauling loot back from areas that are a short distance from the two residing safe zones. The pvp is pretty fun, most players don't have armor. There is no durability for armor. There is no weight system. The guns seem to be pretty unbalances where as a shotgun has little spread and is typically able to one-shot players at an absurd range and for some reason an M4 out-guns an AK greatly. I believe the balances should be as so; The AK has more recoil but does more damage per shot / has slightly slower firerate vs. the M4 that is easier to control, and higher firerate. Weapon modding is super basic, only 3 reflex sight attachables and a flashlight. Can't store modded weapons to traders. Basebuilding is seemly balanced, not so sure about raiding. Overall for an early access release the game seems promising and if the devs work hard and listen to community opinion I believe this game will really flourish in due time.

Don't waste your money on this game - even if it's on sale. It had massive potential in the beginning and was really enjoyable. I have over 1,300 hours in it, but I can't be bothered to play it anymore. Many of Deadside's inherent problems have already been mentioned by other reviewers and the occasional streamer, so I won't waste time repeating them. 

The development speed is glacial. There are fundamental problems with Deadside that the devs either cannot or will not fix and this has resulted in a rapidly dwindling player base. 

If you dare be honest about the state of the game in the Steam discussions, a belligerent dev will send you a sarcastic message and ban you from the discussion. You have been warned!!!

151228570.review:
I think this game is really good as it stands and is easily worth the money the devs are asking for. However I do think its got a decent way to go before it becomes a proper finished survival game.

Now the main selling point to me with this game is it very similar to "DayZ" but without so much of the boring survival stuff. 
This game offers a similar experience to "DayZ" but lets you get guns and gear fairly quickly with the added benefit of AI bots roaming around to keep things interesting along with being a source for loot. This game also had no zombies which is a plus for me as in my opinion "DayZ" zombies are terrible and something like "Scum" offers a better all round survival experience when compared to "DayZ".

Now in terms of improvements I think the missions really need improving with more variety. Basically the missions as they stand is go into an area and kill all the bots to get a reward. While I think this is a good starting point it gets boring fast in my opinion. The convoys were a cool idea but I find nobody bothers to try and steal the loot therefore it doesn't work too great in practice. Perhaps adding objectives to some of the missions making them harder would work better if done properly. Also im not a fan of the respawn system. Basically when you die you can choose which town you want to spawn in which means when you kill a player they just spawn 100m or so away and instantly come back. I would much prefer random imo. 

Okay some others things I would like to see to make this the perfect game is more points of interest in the current map ( Not expanding as the map has plenty of free space at the moment ). Making cities and towns more useful such as adding a police station and hospital as a place for basic guns, armour and an easy way to get medical supplies which is very difficult atm. Also perhaps having an NPC which gives some basic quests for money or items would be cool. An example of a quest could be goto "Stepnoe" find a golden watch and bring it back here. This would also promote going to towns and cities along with increasing PVP in these areas. Some sort of weather system would also be greatly practised adding much variety and sounds to the environment making it feel more real and immersive.

Anyway thanks for reading this lengthy recommendation / review for this game.

Overall if you like the look of the game just buy it.

123764358.review: This was a really good game until the 0,4.0 update. The few previous updates started its decline. Originally they stated the reason they did not include zombies into the game was because they did not want it to be too much like DayZ. Well, with the last 3 updates the game has become more and more like DayZ. I really liked this game for it's differences from DayZ. Now, it seems as if the fun is leaving the game. The survival mechanics and re-do of the base building have made the game an endless grind instead of the "easy to jump into game" that it was. My hopes are that enough of the players who do not like the changes speak up and the devs listen. But, I cannot recommend this game at this time.
